thig15.1:10.3: 'chādeti' usually means "covers/conceals" - perhaps similar to how someone will put a cloth or lid over food on a platter or in a pot when bringing it out to serve to others, then removes the covering at the last minute. So the meaning would be something like "I covered, brought out, and gave to them whatever was proper."
thig15.1:12.1: "bow for hair" is based on the variant reading of 'pasāda' as 'pāsaka'. Aka "hairband" or "hair-tie".
thig15.1:16.4: could also say "Why doesn't she please you, son?" or "Why does she displease you, son?" or "How..?" [instead of 'why']
thig15.1:42.2: [lit. "I held a cart" or "I endured a cart"]
thig15.1:42.3: My first reading of this is "afflicted with blindness and unwell" [andha+vaṭṭa]. If you take 'andhova' as "unwashed" then you might render this phrase as "unwashed, afflicted, and unwell,"
thig15.1:43.2: The inclusion of the word 'ghare' in the Pāli seems inexplicable, and I have a hard time rationalizing its presence, except perhaps by taking it in a metaphorical sense of meaning "state of being" rather than literal meaning of "house". Overall, I strongly suspect that the intended meaning of this phrase is actually "I was born as a female street-slave", which would also help clarify the following phrase [since it clearly establishes the female physiology of the person's body].
thig15.1:43.3: The term Mahilā only appears twice In the Pāli Canon. It has been previously translated as 'woman', from the similar Sanskrit word that has this meaning. I find this translation not in accordance with Dhamma. It seems more likely to me that this is a compound of the Pāli ‘mah + la,’ worthy. This would indicate a lack of honor and respect, which would make more sense in the text, given that it refers to a state of enslavement in this particular rebirth.
thig15.1:45.4: as I was dragged away wailing.
